question: Question_07_(a)
statement:
\emph{Streptococcus viridans} bacteria divide along a preferred axis and
therefore form chains when they divide. You study a population of
\emph{S. viridans} in a blood culture. Let \emph{X} be the length (in
Âµm) of a randomly chosen chain. Its distribution is described by the
probability density function

\begin{align*}p(x) = \frac1{x}, \quad 1 \leq x \leq e\end{align*}

Find the expected length of a chain (i.e. the expected value of
\emph{X}).

$E[X]=$
sols:
To find the expected lenght, we multiply the length \emph{x} with the
probability density function \emph{p(x)} and integrate over all possible
lengths. In other words, the mean, or expected value, \emph{E{[}X{]}} is
given by

\begin{align*}E[X] = \int_a^b xp(x)\,dx.\end{align*}

In this problem \emph{a} = 1, \emph{b} = \emph{e} and \emph{p(x)} =
1/\emph{x}, thus

\begin{align*}E[X] = \int_1^e x\cdot \frac1x dx = \int_1^e\,dx = x|_1^e = e-1.\end{align*}
hints: Use the formula for the continuous expected value.
